Spot the Error in given sentence | Govt Exam Tricks & PYQs

Master Error Detection in English for SSC, Banking, Railways, and all Competitive Exams!

ğŸ” Introduction

Error detection is one of the most scoring yet tricky sections in English for government exams like SSC CGL, CHSL, Banking, Railways, CDS, and others. In just a few seconds, you must spot a grammatical or structural mistake in a sentence. The good news? With the right approach and pattern recognition, you can solve each question in under 5 seconds!

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: The trick is not reading the sentence fast â€” it's reading it smartly. Look for common patterns of errors first.

ğŸš€ 5-Second Trick Strategy

  • Step 1: Quickly identify the sentence type â€” tense, voice, or conditional.
  • Step 2: Look for subject-verb agreement first (the most common error type).
  • Step 3: Check prepositions â€” theyâ€™re short but sneaky!
  • Step 4: Verify articles, determiners, and tenses.
  • Step 5: Finally, scan the meaning â€” sometimes logic reveals the error.
âš¡ Quick Hack: 80% of "find the error" questions are from just 5 topics â€” Subject-Verb, Tenses, Articles, Prepositions, and Parallelism.

ğŸ§  Common Error Categories with Examples

1ï¸âƒ£ Subject-Verb Agreement

âŒ The list of items are on the table.
âœ… The list of items is on the table.

Always match the verb with the main subject, not the noun nearest to it.

2ï¸âƒ£ Tense Consistency

âŒ He has completed his work before you came.
âœ… He had completed his work before you came.

When two actions occur in the past, the earlier action takes Past Perfect.

3ï¸âƒ£ Preposition Errors

âŒ He is good in English.
âœ… He is good at English.

Some words always take fixed prepositions â€” memorize them with short tricks.

4ï¸âƒ£ Articles & Determiners

âŒ She is a honest girl.
âœ… She is an honest girl.

5ï¸âƒ£ Parallelism

âŒ He likes reading, to write, and singing.
âœ… He likes reading, writing, and singing.

âš™ï¸ Quick Tricks & Mnemonics

  • ğŸ”¹ Preposition Fix: "Good at", "Interested in", "Depend on", "Accused of".
  • ğŸ”¹ Subject-Verb Rule: Each, Every, Either, Neither â†’ take singular verb.
  • ğŸ”¹ Neitherâ€¦nor â†’ verb agrees with the nearest subject.
  • ğŸ”¹ â€œA number ofâ€ â†’ plural verb | â€œThe number ofâ€ â†’ singular verb.
  • ğŸ”¹ Little/Few â†’ Negative sense | A little/A few â†’ Positive sense.
ğŸ¯ Memory Trick: â€œOne Word, One Verbâ€ â€” Donâ€™t repeat verbs unnecessarily. Example: âŒ He did not went. âœ… He did not go.

ğŸ“˜ Previous Year Questions (PYQs)

PYQ 1: Each of the boys have done their homework.
âœ… Correct: Each of the boys has done his homework.
PYQ 2: No sooner he reached the station when the train left.
âœ… Correct: No sooner did he reach the station than the train left.
PYQ 3: He is one of the best player in the team.
âœ… Correct: He is one of the best players in the team.
PYQ 4: Neither of the two friends were invited.
âœ… Correct: Neither of the two friends was invited.
PYQ 5: The scenery of Kashmir are beautiful.
âœ… Correct: The scenery of Kashmir is beautiful.
PYQ 6: The teacher asked me that why was I late.
âœ… Correct: The teacher asked me why I was late.
PYQ 7: He prefers coffee than tea.
âœ… Correct: He prefers coffee to tea.

ğŸ’¬ 15 Most Asked FAQs

Q1. What is â€œFind the Errorâ€ question in exams?

Itâ€™s a sentence divided into parts â€” one part has a grammatical error, and you must identify it.

Q2. Which topics are most common?

Subject-verb agreement, articles, tenses, prepositions, and modifiers.

Q3. How can I solve error detection in 5 seconds?

Spot the subject and verb first. If they donâ€™t agree in number or tense, thatâ€™s your answer!

Q4. Are vocabulary errors asked?

Rarely. Focus on grammar-based errors first.

Q5. Is â€œFind the Errorâ€ the same as Sentence Improvement?

No, in â€œFind the Errorâ€ you only find the wrong part, not correct it.

Q6. How many questions come in SSC exams?

Usually 3â€“5 questions in Tier-I, and more detailed ones in Tier-II.

Q7. How do I practice?

Use PYQs from SSC CGL, CHSL, Bank PO papers, and online quizzes.

Q8. How do I remember grammar rules?

Make short notes and revise through examples. Use flashcards or daily mock tests.

Q9. Whatâ€™s the most ignored area?

Prepositions and parallel structure â€” theyâ€™re small but tricky.

Q10. Should I read the full sentence first?

No. Scan for structure â€” check subject, verb, connectors, then meaning.

Q11. What is the fastest way to spot tense errors?

Look for time indicators like â€œbeforeâ€, â€œafterâ€, â€œsinceâ€, â€œby the timeâ€. They often signal tense issues.

Q12. How do I spot article errors?

Check if the noun is countable, singular, and known to the reader. â€œA/Anâ€ = first mention; â€œTheâ€ = known.

Q13. Do all exams follow the same pattern?

Mostly yes â€” SSC, Banking, and Railways have similar grammar focus.

Q14. Can I skip reading comprehension to focus on error detection?

No, both are important. But error detection takes less time and gives quicker marks.

Q15. How can I build accuracy?

Practice daily and review every mistake. Remember: repetition builds reflex!

ğŸ Final Tips

  • ğŸ”¹ Practice at least 20 questions daily.
  • ğŸ”¹ Note every new grammar rule you discover.
  • ğŸ”¹ Time yourself â€” accuracy + speed wins exams.
  • ğŸ”¹ Read English newspapers or articles to develop intuition for correct grammar.
ğŸŒŸ Golden Rule: â€œWhen confused, check the verb.â€ Most errors hide in verbs â€” agreement, form, or tense!
